DOC.HEAD: Shiite Groups Battle in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias fought in south Lebanon Monday for a third day with grenades and mortars. Six people died and 42 were wounded, police said. The casualties brought the three-day toll to 38 killed, 150 wounded, police said. Police said the Syrian-armed Amal and its rival, Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, poured tank fire, mortar shells and rockets on each other's strongholds all afternoon in Ein Kama and Kfar Kila villages in the al-Tuffah region. Each accused the other of starting the fighting in the villages about five miles northeast of Sidon, south Lebanon's provincial capital. The latest round of fighting began before dawn Saturday when Hezbollah overran four Amal-held villages. Amal rushed in reinforcements Sunday and recaptured two villages. The two factions have fought for 2{ years for supremacy over Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Since May 1987, such fighting has killed 609 people and wounded 1,719.
